findings.label: Suppliers with Current Red Flags
findings.detail: 9 current suppliers have Companies House compliance issues (historical payments were made before breaches started)

findings.label: Likely Duplicate Payments
findings.detail: 96 high-confidence duplicate groups with same supplier, amount, date and reference (3+ copies) (after filtering 776 CSV republication artifacts)
findings.context_note: Quarterly CSV overlaps (same transaction appearing in 2 files) have been filtered out. Remaining duplicates show 3+ identical copies, which are more likely genuine overpayments.

findings.label: Suspected Split Payments
findings.detail: 1 instances of 3+ payments just below approval thresholds in the same week
findings.context_note: Split payment detection has a high false-positive rate. Batch processing, staged invoices, and legitimate recurring payments can all trigger this pattern. FOI request for procurement approval chain recommended before drawing conclusions.

findings.label: Round-Number Payments (>£5K)
findings.detail: 175 exact round-number payments over £5,000 — may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts

findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: Community Capital spent 12.8x their monthly average in March (£1.1M above normal). Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years' March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Rapid Payment Suppliers
findings.detail: 12 suppliers receive payments every <14 days on average. Top: Redacted Personal Data (2.5 day avg, 1145 payments, £790.2K)

findings.label: Benford's Law Anomaly
findings.detail: Significant deviation from Benford's Law (p < 0.001). Digit 1 deviates 11.9% from expected distribution across 13,320 transactions. Note: with 13,320 transactions, chi-squared tests are highly sensitive — the 11.9% max digit deviation is the more practical measure of anomaly.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 13,320+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (11.9%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

findings.label: Second-Digit Benford's Anomaly
findings.detail: Second-digit distribution across 13,325 transactions shows p < 0.001 (highly significant). Digit 5 deviates 6.28% from Nigrini's expected distribution. Second-digit tests are more discriminating than first-digit for detecting round-number bias and fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Benford's second-digit analysis (Nigrini, 2012) uses chi-squared with 9 df. Critical values: 16.92 (p=0.05), 21.67 (p=0.01), 27.88 (p=0.001). n=13,325.

findings.label: High-Risk Councillors
findings.detail: 5 councillors scored 'high risk' in integrity assessment across 8 data sources. Most common flags: undeclared interests, supplier conflicts, and company compliance issues.

key_findings.title: 2 suppliers with clock-like payment regularity
key_findings.description: These suppliers receive payments at near-identical intervals (std dev <5 days). Top: Redacted Personal Data — every 2.5 days (1145 payments, £790.2K)

key_findings.title: REDACTED PERSONAL DATA: 1145 transactions totalling £790.2K
key_findings.description: Averaging £690 per transaction — the council's most frequent supplier

key_findings.title: 8 suppliers shared with neighbouring councils — £3.8M total
key_findings.description: Compare what each council pays the same suppliers for similar services

key_findings.title: CHUBB FIRE & SECURITY LTD: 7066% price gap between councils
key_findings.description: Blackpool pays £28.1K avg vs Rossendale £392 (both with 3+ transactions). Compared using 2 common financial years. Price differences may reflect different service scope, contract terms, or volumes rather than overcharging — manual review recommended.
key_findings.context_note: Cross-council price comparisons use common financial years only (where both councils have data for the same supplier). This prevents unfair comparisons between councils with different data periods. Differences may still reflect different service levels or contract terms.

signals.signal: Year-end spike: 12.8x monthly average in March
9 suppliers with current CH red flags

fraud_triangle.methodology: Fraud triangle (Cressey 1953): screening tool synthesising existing DOGE analysis signals. Not an accusation of fraud.

budget_variance.caveat: AI DOGE tracks spending >£500 only (5 financial years annualised). GOV.UK outturn is all expenditure for 2024-25. Coverage ratios reflect threshold differences, not missing data.
